channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Businesswoman’s Fate a Test of China’s Resolve on North Korea
item.media:description: Friendship Bridge, linking Dandong, China, to North Korea. From the border city, the Chinese businesswoman Ma Xiaohong conducted trade that American officials say violated international sanctions.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: The fate of Ma Xiaohong, and the business empire she built on trade with North Korea, has become a measure of China’s willingness to confront its neighbor.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: Ecuador Gives Assange Citizenship, Worsening Standoff With Britain
item.media:description: Julian Assange speaking at the Ecuadorean Embassy in London last year.
item.description: Ecuador wants the WikiLeaks founder to leave its London embassy, but Britain insists that he face justice, which could include extradition to the United States.
item.dc:creator: MAGGY AYALA and STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Pollution Appears to Ease in Beijing Amid China’s Drive to Clear the Air
item.media:description: Blue skies are more common in Beijing these days. A Greenpeace analysis of government data found that pollution levels had dropped 53 percent in the last three months of 2017 from a year earlier.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: A Greenpeace analysis found that air quality had drastically improved in several northeastern cities, but regions far from the capital have not seen the same results.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: German Idea to Fight Anti-Semitism: Make Immigrants Tour Concentration Camps
item.media:description: The former Auschwitz concentration camp, a legacy of Nazi Germany, is now a museum in Poland.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: Jewish advocacy groups welcomed an idea to make such tours mandatory for immigrants to Germany. But some experts called the idea simplistic.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: North Korea Praises ‘Fire and Fury’ Book on Trump Administration
item.media:description: Retailers in the United States are having trouble keeping “Fire and Fury” in stock. Pirated copies of the book are already circulating online in Asia.
item.description: The popularity of the book, which chronicles dysfunction in the White House, “foretells President Trump’s political demise,” North Korean state media said.
item.dc:creator: GERRY MULLANY
item.category: Fire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House (Book)

item.title: ‘The New Normal’ in Pakistan: a Journalist on the Run From Gunmen
item.media:description: Taha Siddiqui, center, a reporter with France 24 and the Pakistan bureau chief for World Is One News, speaks during a news conference in Islamabad on Wednesday.
item.description: Taha Siddiqui, a reporter and frequent critic of Pakistan’s military, escaped an attack by a dozen men who diverted his car just outside the capital.
item.dc:creator: MEHREEN ZAHRA-MALIK
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Archidona Journal: Short on Space for Migrants, Spain Sent Them to a Town’s New Prison
item.media:description: A protest outside the new prison in Archidona, Spain, in November, where nearly 500 Algerian migrants were being held.
item.description: Their arrival has provoked mixed feelings in the town, with some protesting their treatment and some concerned about possible damaged to the prison before its opening.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: South Korea’s Leader Credits Trump for North Korea Talks
item.media:description: President Moon Jae-in of South Korea during a televised news conference in Seoul on Wednesday.
item.description: President Moon Jae-in warned North Korea about sanctions if it resumed weapons tests, while crediting President Trump with forcing it to the table.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Pope Invites the Poor to the Circus, and Animal Activists Protest
item.media:description: A recent visit by circus performers inspired the Vatican to arrange a gift of circus tickets to thousands of poor people.
item.description: The Vatican’s charity office secured free tickets for 2,100 people, among them the homeless and refugees, but some critics quickly spoke up.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: U.S. Bombs Afghan Militia Behind Insider Attack, Officials Say
item.media:description: American forces and Afghan troops on patrol last year in the Achin district of Nangarhar Province, Afghanistan. Nangarhar has been the deadliest province for American forces in the past year.
item.description: American forces carried out airstrikes against an allied Afghan militia after at least one militia member opened fire on U.S. soldiers in eastern Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: ZABIHULLAH GHAZI and MUJIB MASHAL
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Pressed on False Claims About Muslims, U.S. Ambassador Goes Silent
item.description: In an exchange with Dutch journalists, Peter Hoekstra declined to clarify his prior remarks. “This is the Netherlands, you have to answer questions,” one reporter said.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Could Britain Have a Second Referendum on ‘Brexit’?
item.media:description: Nigel Farage, center, in London after the 2016 referendum on “Brexit.” The right-wing politician said on Thursday, “Maybe, just maybe, I’m reaching the point of thinking we should have a second referendum on E.U. membership.”
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: Now, even Nigel Farage, the driving force behind the campaign to leave the European Union, is musing about a new vote. How realistic is that?
item.dc:creator: ILIANA MAGRA

item.title: She Left France to Fight in Syria. Now She Wants to Return. But Can She?
item.media:description: An image released by the Kurdish Syrian forces this week showed Emilie König, a 33-year-old suspected of recruiting fighters for the Islamic State, at an undisclosed location in Syria.
item.media:credit: YPG Press Office, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The case of a woman in France who became a prominent propagandist for the Islamic State is unusual, but points to a broader quandary for Europe.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Once an ISIS Recruiter, She Now Wants Out
item.description: A woman who left France and became a prominent propagandist and recruiter for the Islamic State has asked her family, friends and country for a pardon. This is how she went from a Paris suburb to the Syrian battlefield.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Gulag Historian Ordered to Undergo Psychiatric Testing in Russia
item.media:description: Yuri A. Dmitriev in June. He was arrested in 2016 on charges of taking indecent photographs of his daughter, then 11.
item.description: Yuri A. Dmitriev was charged with possessing child pornography, but his real crime seems to have been documenting Stalin’s crimes.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Same-Sex Spouses Should Have E.U. Residency Rights, Court Is Told
item.media:description: Claibourn Robert Hamilton, left, an American, married Adrian Coman, a Romanian, in Belgium in 2010. Romania, which does not recognize same-sex unions, denied Mr. Hamilton spousal residency rights.
item.description: All married couples should be allowed to live and work across the European Union, regardless of member countries’ laws on same-sex unions, the bloc’s top court was advised.
item.dc:creator: KIT GILLET
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
Court of Justice of the European Union

item.title: Gajah Makmur Journal: Wildlife Detectives Pursue the Case of Dwindling Elephants in Indonesia
item.media:description: Barokah, an elephant rider, giving a health check to Nelson, a trained elephant at a conservation center in the province of Bengkulu in Indonesia.
item.media:credit: Kemal Jufri for The New York Times
item.description: Advocacy groups are going undercover to help the police track down poachers and using unconventional means to save the animals.
item.dc:creator: JON EMONT

item.title: House Votes to Renew Surveillance Law, Rejecting New Privacy Protections
item.media:description: A yearslong effort by a bipartisan group of lawmakers to impose significant new privacy limits on the NSA’s warrantless surveillance program fell short on Thursday.
item.description: House lawmakers voted to preserve the National Security Agency’s warrantless surveillance program.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE, EILEEN SULLIVAN and NICHOLAS FANDOS

item.title: Marriott to China: We Do Not Support Separatists
item.media:description: A JW Marriott hotel in Beijing. The Marriott hotel chain is under investigation in China after it listed Tibet and Taiwan as countries.
item.description: The hotel chain apologizes after a poorly worded customer survey prompts a political backlash and an investigation by Chinese officials.
item.dc:creator: SUI-LEE WEE

item.title: Rome’s Famous Christmas Tree to Be Reborn as a Baby Nursing Station
item.media:description: A worker reinstalling the star on top of Rome’s Christmas tree, known as “Spelacchio,” or mangy, on Tuesday. The tree was taken down on Thursday.
item.description: The tree, known as Spelacchio, or mangy, was dismantled Thursday, but the much-maligned spruce will live on, in the hearts of Romans, and in a book.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Fighting Rages in Syria’s Last Major Insurgent Stronghold
item.media:description: Two Syrian sisters running to embrace after finding each other following an air strike on the rebel-held Eastern Ghouta area near Damascus on Tuesday.
item.description: The United Nations said assaults by Russian-backed Syrian forces in Idlib Province had put tens of thousands of civilians at risk.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Vatican Takes Over Troubled Catholic Group in Peru Ahead of Pope’s Visit
item.description: The founder of the group has been accused of sexually and physically abusing children and former members of the group.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Belgium in Uproar Over Torture of Sudanese It Deported
item.media:description: A demonstration in Brussels last month against the deportation policies of Belgium’s secretary for asylum and migration, Theo Francken.
item.description: Reports that migrants were tortured upon their return to Sudan are provoking calls for the migration minister to resign.
item.dc:creator: MILAN SCHREUER
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Egypt Opens Criminal Inquiry Over New York Times Article
item.media:description: The Western Wall and the Dome of the Rock in Jerusalem. Egypt officially supports a future Palestinian state with East Jerusalem as its capital.
item.description: The Times reported on a secret effort by Egyptian intelligence to sway public opinion on Jerusalem. Officials say the article hurt national security.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: 7-Eleven, California, Tonya Harding: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: Arrest in Chechnya Reflects Effort to Drive Out Dissidents, Activists Say
item.media:description: Oyub Titiev, a human rights activist working in Chechnya, has made an “invaluable contribution over many years,” a Council of Europe official said.
item.description: Oyub Titiev, who has run a human rights group since the unsolved murder of a member of the group, is the latest in a series of government critics to face drug charges.
item.dc:creator: SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: A Colombian Rebel Group Resumes Attacks After Cease-Fire Ends
item.media:description: A crater left after an attack in the eastern department of Arauca, Colombia. The government on Wednesday blamed a rebel group, the National Liberation Army, also known as the ELN.
item.media:credit: Ecopetrol, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: While no deaths were reported, the attacks highlighted the challenges Colombia faces in negotiating a peace deal with the ELN rebel group similar to the one it signed with the larger FARC group.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: India Extends Hand to Apple and Others by Easing Rules on Foreign Firms
item.media:description: An ad for Apple’s iPad on a store in New Delhi, India. The Indian government said Wednesday it was easing rules that have made it difficult for single-brand foreign companies from opening stores in the country.
item.description: The government said foreign-owned, single-brand retailers would get more time to meet its requirements to sell products made by Indians.
item.dc:creator: VINDU GOEL and SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: The Interpreter: When Corporate Elites Won Partial Control of a Mexican City — and Then Lost It
item.media:description: A restaurant in San Pedro Garza García, an affluent enclave of Monterrey, Mexico. Outside the city’s wealthy areas, violence and corruption daily are often part of the daily routine.
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.description: Monterrey’s experiment in reducing crime offers a concerning lesson for any country with weak institutions.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER and AMANDA TAUB

item.title: 2 Die as Pakistanis Protest Over Girl’s Killing
item.media:description: The funeral on Wednesday of Zainab Amin, a young girl who was found dead, apparently strangled, in Kasur, Pakistan.
item.description: Hundreds protested in outrage over the death of the girl, one of about a dozen children killed in the city of Kasur over the past two years.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: 13,000 Tourists Stranded in a Swiss Ski Resort for 2 Days
item.media:description: While rail and road access was closed, a helicopter service was the only way out of Zermatt, Switzerland.
item.description: A combination of snow and rain shut off access to Zermatt, near the Matterhorn. Until late Wednesday afternoon, helicopter was the only way out.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: ISIS Declares War on Hamas, and Gaza Families Disown Sons in Sinai
item.media:description: A Gaza man, Hamza al-Zamli, second from left, orders the execution of a captive accused of smuggling weapons to Hamas in a propaganda video by the Sinai branch of the Islamic State.
item.description: A shocking video from the Islamic State’s Sinai branch showed one former Gazan instructing another to kill a man accused of smuggling weapons to Hamas.
item.dc:creator: IYAD ABUHEWEILA and ISABEL KERSHNER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Iran Eases Death Penalty for Drug Crimes, Saving Potentially Thousands of Lives
item.media:description: An execution noose in Noor, Iran.
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi/Iranian Students News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: A rare overhaul by Iran’s hard-line dominated judiciary came amid domestic and international pressure to reduce its executions, which are second only to China’s.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Greece Scraps Compulsory Shariah for Muslim Minority
item.media:description: Residents of Komotini, Greece, outside the Kirmahalle Cammi mosque last month. Muslims in the northern region of Thrace, which includes Komotini, will have the option of going to a Greek court to resolve family disputes.
item.description: Lawmakers passed legislation allowing Muslims in Thrace, a northern region, to take civilian cases to Greek courts rather than to Islamic clerics.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: In Rural Nepal, Menstruation Taboo Claims Another Victim
item.media:description: Women and their children in a chhaupadi hut in western Nepal in September. Nepal’s government has been trying to discourage the chhaupadi tradition, in which menstruating women are banished from the home.
item.description: Many women in rural Nepal sleep outdoors when they are menstruating, because of a belief that they are impure. This week, one such woman died in the cold.
item.dc:creator: BHADRA SHARMA and JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Libya Rescues 279 Migrants at Sea, but 100 More Are Feared Dead
item.media:description: Migrants were taken to a naval base in Tripoli, Libya, on Tuesday after being rescued by the country’s coast guard.
item.description: All of the survivors, including 19 women and 17 children, were handed over to the country’s anti-migration authority.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Catalan Separatists Seek to Re-elect Puigdemont
item.media:description: Carles Puigdemont joined a campaign meeting in Barcelona last month via video link from Brussels. He has not said whether he intends to return to Catalonia.
item.description: The main separatist parties have a deal to keep Carles Puigdemont as the Catalan leader, even though he is still in self-imposed exile in Belgium.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Another Search Begins for Long-Missing Malaysian Airliner
item.media:description: An undated photo showing the launch of one of Ocean Infinity’s underwater search vehicles. The company could receive as much as $70 million if it finds Flight 370’s debris field or two data recorders within 90 days.
item.description: A Houston-based company could be paid tens of millions of dollars if it finds Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, which vanished in 2014 with 239 people aboard.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Reuters Reporters Are Charged in Myanmar With Obtaining State Secrets
item.media:description: The Reuters journalists U Wa Lone, center front, and U Kyaw Soe Oo, center back, were escorted by the police in Yangon, Myanmar, on Wednesday, after being charged with obtaining state secrets.
item.description: The two journalists, who had been investigating the existence of a mass grave, could face up to 14 years in prison.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH and SAW NANG

item.title: Chinese General Under Investigation, Joining a Line of Fallen Commanders
item.media:description: Gen. Fang Fenghui, center, with Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr., the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, in Beijing in August.
item.description: Gen. Fang Fenghui has become the latest in a succession of People’s Liberation Army commanders to face corruption charges.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: U.S. to Open Formal Inquiry on Americans Sickened in Cuba
item.media:description: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, center, with Senator Ron Johnson of Wisconsin, left, at the Capitol on Tuesday as lawmakers discussed the illnesses that struck American diplomats in Havana in 2016.
item.description: Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson is opening an investigation into what the government has described as mysterious attacks that sickened or injured 24 Americans in Havana in 2016.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: El Salvador Again Feels the Hand of Washington Shaping Its Fate
item.media:description: Downtown San Salvador on Tuesday. “It’s going to be chaos,” said one resident of the effect of the Trump administration’s decision to cancel a program that gave Salvadorans temporary status in the United States.
item.media:credit: Fred Ramos for The New York Times
item.description: It has suffered from a civil war and gang violence, and is now bracing for the return of nearly 200,000 Salvadorans who have been living in the United States.
item.dc:creator: GENE PALUMBO and AZAM AHMED

item.title: Bannon, North Korea, El Salvador: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: On Olympics: North Korea Makes Peace With the Olympics
item.media:description: North Korean figure skaters Ryom Tae-ok and Kim Ju-sik, performing in September, are likely to represent their country at the Olympics in South Korea next month.
item.media:credit: Jun Michael Park for The New York Times
item.description: North Korea announced it will participate in the Olympics next month, easing tensions with South Korea and providing a boost for the Olympic movement.
item.dc:creator: JERÉ LONGMAN

item.title: ‘You Can’t Survive Anymore’: Tunisia Protests Rising Prices and Taxes
item.media:description: Police vehicles stopped in front of burning tires set up by people protesting rising prices and taxes on Tuesday in Tunis.
item.description: Economic anxieties have roiled the country, the only nation to emerge from the Arab Spring uprisings with the semblance of a stable democracy.
item.dc:creator: LILIA BLAISE
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

item.title: ‘Fire and Fury’ From Canada: It’s Not About Trump. Or Michael Wolff.
item.media:description: It’s not that “Fire and Fury.”
item.description: A scholarly analysis by a Canadian professor of World War II bombing of Germany has found new life because it shares part of the title of the political best seller.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.category: Fire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House (Book)
Fire and Fury: The Allied Bombing of Germany, 1942-1945 (Book)

item.title: As Electric Cars’ Prospects Brighten, Japan Fears Being Left Behind
item.media:description: A Jatco factory in Fuji, Japan. An immediate, total shift to electric vehicles “would kill my business,” said Terry Nakatsuka, the carmaker’s chief executive.
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.description: The country, which missed out on some earlier technological shifts, is now scrambling to catch up as the world warms up to battery-powered vehicles.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: In Ukraine, a Successful Fight for Justice, Then a Murder
item.media:description: Kateryna Dunyak, Iryna Nozdrovska’s mother, crying on her daughter’s coffin in the village of Demydiv, Ukraine, on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Alexey Furman for The New York Times
item.description: Iryna Nozdrovska, a human rights lawyer, fought a corrupt court to put her sister’s killer behind bars. She was stabbed to death after winning the case.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
